transcript: Woman: Um, I work for the Department of Education and I've seen that there's quite a big difference between public versus private. I was wondering if we're getting any sort of funding towards public education in the near future.
Moderator: Might go uh Mr. Dutton, kick that one off.

Dutton: Well, I think it's an incredibly important question and it's important because parents have a choice to make and whether that's for the public system or for the private system, we have supported both and we support increased funding going into this election as well and there's a position which is identical between the two parties in relation to funding for public schools and for private schools as well. Uh I think it is important that parents are able to have that choice and that we can fund the infrastructure and that we can support teacher development and make sure that we've got an education system which is fit for purpose. We live in an incredibly competitive environment and we need to make sure that the outcomes in our schools are meeting the standards and expectations.

Albanese: Well, thanks very much Monica for your question and I admire anyone who is a public school teacher. Uh you do incredible work. And one of the things we've had to deal with is the last time government changed in Australia in 2013, in the 2014 budget 30 billion dollars was ripped out of public schools in that budget. 50 billion dollars was ripped out of hospitals. And we've had to deal with that for a long time. You'd be aware way back now, more than a decade ago, there was the Gonski reforms which were about giving, put simply, every child to get free, a fair funding. So that if they fall behind, they can get that assistance. Now we've delivered that in a deal negotiated with every single state and territory in the country. 14.6 billion of

Albanese: additional dollars so that every student whether they are going to a public school or a private school can get the funding that they deserve and that includes the deal so that they get proper proper support so that if a child falls behind at the moment NAPLAN is a bit too late we want to do testing in year one so if a child falls behind they can get that specialist one on one tutoring or small group to make sure that they don't fall behind because if you address that really early then every child can have the opportunity to fulfill their aspirations.
Moderator: Kieran I just wanted to follow up on that real quickly.
Moderator: The fact is, that there were no cuts.

Moderator: The Prime Minister goes out with this medicare campaign and education scare campaign, it is not a truthful statement. Now what the Prime Minister is saying is that the funding didn't go up by as much as he would want each year, but there was no year where funding was cut from hospitals or...

Moderator: So if we ask why we've got a housing crisis and why it's difficult, we can point to that because there's massive demand for housing, and Australian kids are missing out, and rents are up by about 18%. I want desperately to make sure we can get an opportunity for young people to believe in and achieve again the dream of homeownership.

Dutton: There's a 42 international students coming into our country for every one student accomodation unit that's been approved. That has had a big impact on the cost of a domestic student going to University. It does change the dynamics within many universities. For example, at the Sydney University, you've now got a much higher mix in terms of international students to domestic students, which changes the dynamic on campus. But I want to make sure that we can get Australian kids into housing as quickly as possible. We can't do that because obviously, if a million people come here over 2 years, that makes an impact.
segment_summary: A woman asks about public education funding, and Dutton responds that both parties support increased funding. Albanese states in the 2014 budget 30 billion was removed from public schools, which the Moderator disputes. The Moderator then discusses a housing crisis and wanting young people to get back into homeownership. There are 42 international students to every student accomodation unit, which changes the dynamics in Universities.

key_arguments.argument: Increased funding for public education is needed.
Both parties support increased funding for both public and private schools.
In the 2014 budget, $30 billion was removed from public schools.
The fact is, there were no cuts.
If a million people come here over 2 years, that has an impact.
High rent creates a housing crisis

rhetorical_analysis.communication_style_notes: Dutton speaks in a measured tone, but then becomes more assertive. Albanese cites funding cuts from the past government, which is refuted. The question from the audience identifies a policy area of key importance.

perspective_commentary.conservative: Dutton's answer will reassure voters that the Coalition supports both public and private education. By stating that the Prime Minister is using scare tactics will be effective. That 10 million people have come over 2 years is impactful to convey.
perspective_commentary.neutral: The response is a commitment to supporting both public and private education. Dutton avoids making specific promises. Dutton makes an argument against the housing crisis to push his agenda.
perspective_commentary.progressive: The housing crisis point should be investigated as it could be affected by more than what Dutton mentions. While Albanese is stating facts about cuts, it could hurt him more as it's not a successful argument for what he's arguing.

connections_to_previous_segments: This segment transitions to the housing market after going through education funding.
interaction_dynamics: The interaction begins with a direct question from a member of the public. Dutton provides a prepared response, then it's passed off to Albanese. Dutton then counters with the Moderator. Then it moves to the housing crisis.
